title.narrative: WASH DEMAND

description.narrative: Parents, caregivers, boys and girls have increased knowledge of the risks of poor Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) practices (open defecation, unsafe water, and lack of handwashing), menstruation and unsafe hygiene management and the skills to adopt safe sanitation and good hygiene practices, particularly in target countries., which contributes to Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, more Pacific children and their families, particularly the most vulnerable, are accessing adequate, equitable, affordable drinking water, sanitation and hygiene.

participating-org.narrative: MINISTRY OF LINE AND PHOENIX DEVELO KIRIBATI

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Parents, caregivers, boys and girls have increased knowledge of the risks of poor WASH practices (open defecation, unsafe water,and lack of handwashing), menstruation and unsafe hygiene management and the skills to adopt safe sanitation and good hygienepractices, particularly in target countries.

description.narrative: The importance of hygiene (i.e., handwashing with soap) was widely promoted across Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PICTs) as part of the COVID-19 risk mitigation approach. Global events as Global Handwashing Day, World Toilet Day and World Water Day also provided opportunities to reiterate the importance of safe water and proper sanitation and hygiene practices. Proper hygiene practices were also promoted through the community-led total sanitation (CLTS) approach in Solomon Island across 62 villages. Hygiene messages were also regularly aired through radio and TV in Fiji as part of the COVID-19 risk communication approach. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:02/02/2022
